introPages.title: Prepositions: function and role
introPages.body:
Prepositions show the relation or position of one thing to another – in space, time, or in abstract senses.

They usually come before a noun or noun phrase: in the room, on Monday, at the door, for a reason.

In Part 2, the gap often needs a preposition – either as part of a phrase (place, time) or as a dependent preposition that always goes with a particular verb, noun, or adjective.

introPages.title: Types: point, line and plane
introPages.body:
One way to think about prepositions of place is by the dimension of the reference:

  • Point – at: at the door, at the corner, at 5 o'clock (time as a point)
  • Line – on: on the wall, on the floor, on Monday (surface or line)
  • Plane/Volume – in: in the room, in the box, in the morning (enclosed space)

This helps explain why we say at the bus stop (point), on the table (surface), in the garden (enclosed area).

introPages.title: Direction and position
introPages.body:
Position (where something is): in, on, at, by, under, above, between, among.

Direction (movement towards/from): to, into, onto, from, out of, through, across.

Examples: stay in the room (position) vs go into the room (direction); lie on the bed vs jump onto the bed.

introPages.title: Time and space
introPages.body:
Time: at 5 o'clock, on Monday, in the morning; for two hours, since last week, during the meeting.

Space: in the city, on the street, at the office; next to, opposite, near, far from.

The point/line/plane idea applies to time too: at a moment, on a day, in a period.

introPages.title: Abstract uses
introPages.body:
Prepositions also express abstract relations:

  • for a reason, because of the weather, in spite of the rain
  • by means of, in terms of, with regard to
  • about the problem, on the subject of, regarding your question

These often appear in fixed phrases. Learn them as whole expressions.

introPages.title: Dependent prepositions with nouns
introPages.body:
Some nouns are always followed by a specific preposition. The preposition is fixed – you must learn the pair.

Examples: reason for, solution to, difference between, interest in, advantage of, need for, lack of, key to, attitude towards, effect on.

In a gap: the reason ___ the delay → for. the key ___ success → to.

introPages.title: Dependent prepositions with verbs
introPages.body:
Many verbs take a fixed preposition before an object. The verb + preposition form a unit.

Examples: depend on, wait for, listen to, look at, aim at, belong to, complain about, apologise for, succeed in, believe in, insist on, object to.

In a gap: it depends ___ the weather → on. she apologised ___ the mistake → for.

introPages.title: Dependent prepositions with adjectives
introPages.body:
Adjectives also have fixed prepositions. The adjective + preposition often describe how someone feels or what they think about something.

Examples: interested in, good at, afraid of, proud of, responsible for, famous for, different from, similar to, compared with, keen on, aware of, capable of.

In a gap: interested ___ music → in. good ___ maths → at. different ___ before → from.

introPages.title: Prepositions in phrasal verbs
introPages.body:
Prepositions (or particles) also appear in phrasal verbs: look into, carry out, give up, take off. Here the preposition/particle completes the verb and often changes its meaning.

In Part 2, a gap may need the particle of a phrasal verb – e.g. look ___ the problem → into. The main section on phrasal verbs covers this in more detail.

For now, remember: verb + preposition pairs (depend on, listen to) are different from phrasal verbs (look into, carry out), but both are common in gaps.

mcQuiz.question: What is the main function of prepositions?
options: To show relation or position of one thing to another
mcQuiz.explanation: Prepositions show the relation or position of one thing to another in space, time, or abstract senses.

mcQuiz.question: Which preposition typically suggests a point?
mcQuiz.explanation: At suggests a point: at the door, at 5 o'clock, at the corner.

mcQuiz.question: Which preposition typically suggests a surface or line?
mcQuiz.explanation: On suggests a surface or line: on the wall, on the floor, on Monday.

mcQuiz.question: Into usually suggests what?
mcQuiz.explanation: Into suggests direction or movement (go into). In suggests position (stay in).

mcQuiz.question: In interested ___ music, which preposition fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Interested is an adjective that takes the dependent preposition 'in'. Interested in + noun.

mcQuiz.question: In it depends ___ the weather, which preposition fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Depend is a verb that takes the dependent preposition 'on'. It depends on + noun.

mcQuiz.question: In the reason ___ the delay, which preposition fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Reason is a noun that takes the dependent preposition 'for'. The reason for + noun.

mcQuiz.question: What is a dependent preposition?
options: A preposition that is fixed with a particular verb, noun or adjective
mcQuiz.explanation: A dependent preposition is fixed – the verb, noun or adjective always takes that specific preposition.

shortQuestions.question: What do prepositions show?
shortQuestions.explanation: Prepositions show the relation or position of one thing to another in space, time, or abstract senses.

shortQuestions.question: Which preposition (at, in, on) suggests a point?
shortQuestions.explanation: At suggests a point: at the door, at 5 o'clock.

shortQuestions.question: Which preposition (at, in, on) suggests a surface?
shortQuestions.explanation: On suggests a surface: on the wall, on the table.

shortQuestions.question: Which preposition (at, in, on) suggests an enclosed space?
shortQuestions.explanation: In suggests an enclosed space or volume: in the room, in the box.

shortQuestions.question: What preposition follows interested?
shortQuestions.explanation: Interested always takes 'in'. Interested in + noun.

shortQuestions.question: What preposition follows depend (e.g. it depends ___)?
shortQuestions.explanation: Depend always takes 'on'. It depends on + noun.

shortQuestions.question: What preposition follows reason (e.g. the reason ___)?
shortQuestions.explanation: Reason always takes 'for'. The reason for + noun.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the difference between a point, a line and a plane in relation to at, on and in.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Point (at): a specific spot – at the door, at 5 o'clock. Line/surface (on): on a line or surface – on the wall, on Monday. Plane/volume (in): inside an area or period – in the room, in the morning.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three examples of verbs that take a dependent preposition.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. depend on, wait for, listen to, look at, apologise for, succeed in, believe in, insist on, object to, aim at.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three examples of adjectives that take a dependent preposition.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. interested in, good at, afraid of, proud of, responsible for, famous for, different from, similar to, keen on, aware of, capable of.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three examples of nouns that take a dependent preposition.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. reason for, solution to, difference between, interest in, advantage of, need for, lack of, key to, attitude towards, effect on.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between in and into?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In = position (where something is). Into = direction (movement towards the inside). e.g. stay in the room vs go into the room.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: How do you know which dependent preposition to use?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: There is no rule – each verb, noun and adjective has its own fixed preposition. You must learn them as pairs: depend + on, interested + in, reason + for, etc.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between a dependent preposition and a phrasal verb particle?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Dependent preposition: the verb/noun/adj has a fixed preposition before its object (depend on, interested in). Phrasal verb: the particle is part of the verb and often changes its meaning (look into = investigate, carry out = perform). Both can appear in Part 2 gaps.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why do we say on Monday but in the morning?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: On + specific day (on Monday, on Christmas Day). In + part of day or longer period (in the morning, in the afternoon, in January, in 2024). At + specific time (at 5 o'clock, at noon).
